title: Tremor, Unspecified
scope: ** Evaluation and diagnostic workup of undifferentiated tremor in adults. Covers the systematic approach to tremor classification (rest, postural, kinetic, intention, task-specific), differentiation of essential tremor, Parkinson tremor, enhanced physiologic tremor, drug-induced tremor, cerebellar tremor, Holmes (rubral) tremor, dystonic tremor, and psychogenic (functional) tremor. Includes DaTscan indications, laboratory workup (thyroid, Wilson disease, medication review), and empiric treatment while awaiting definitive diagnosis. Settings: ED, HOSP, OPD. Excludes definitive management of established diagnoses (see Essential Tremor, Parkinson's Disease, Drug-Induced Parkinsonism, Dystonia, Functional Neurological Disorder templates for ongoing management after diagnosis confirmed).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hyperthyroidism is a common reversible cause of enhanced physiologic tremor; hypothyroidism rarely causes tremor
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal (0.4-4.0 mIU/L); abnormal TSH triggers free T4; hyperthyroidism identified directs treatment of underlying cause

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Order if TSH abnormal; confirms hyper- or hypothyroidism as cause of tremor
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; elevated confirms hyperthyroidism contributing to tremor

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolyte derangements (hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, uremia, hepatic dysfunction) cause or worsen tremor
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, liver failure, renal failure all produce tremor

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia is an acute reversible cause of tremor; hyperglycemia with diabetic neuropathy
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal (70-100 mg/dL fasting); hypoglycemia triggers treatment and tremor resolves

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: General health assessment; infection screen; anemia workup
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; leukocytosis suggests infectious or inflammatory cause

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Drug-induced tremor is one of the most common causes; review ALL current medications including OTC, herbal, and supplements
Essential/Core Labs.target: Complete medication list; identify tremor-inducing agents (valproate, lithium, SSRIs, stimulants, bronchodilators, amiodarone, metoclopramide, antipsychotics)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Excessive caffeine is a leading cause of enhanced physiologic tremor; often overlooked
Essential/Core Labs.target: Quantify daily caffeine intake (coffee, tea, energy drinks, supplements); >400 mg/day causes significant tremor

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Wilson disease screening in patients <50 years or with atypical features (hepatic dysfunction, psychiatric symptoms, Kayser-Fleischer rings)
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: 20-40 mg/dL; low (<20 mg/dL) triggers 24-hour urine copper and slit-lamp exam for K-F rings

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Wilson disease confirmation if ceruloplasmin low or borderline
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: <40 mcg/24h normal; >100 mcg/24h strongly suggestive of Wilson disease

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Wilson disease evaluation alongside ceruloplasmin; copper deficiency causes neurological symptoms
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal (70-140 mcg/dL); low total copper with low ceruloplasmin indicates Wilson disease

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Wilson disease screening; hepatic encephalopathy; medication hepatotoxicity
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal; abnormal triggers evaluation for Wilson disease, hepatic tremor

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Deficiency causes tremor, neuropathy, and myelopathy contributing to movement disorder
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: >400 pg/mL; borderline (200-400) triggers methylmalonic acid; deficiency triggers supplementation

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Drug toxicity is a common and reversible cause of tremor; supratherapeutic levels worsen EPS
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Therapeutic ranges; supratherapeutic levels require dose adjustment or discontinuation

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Identify sympathomimetics, illicit substances (amphetamines, cocaine), or other toxins causing tremor
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; positive identifies offending agent for targeted management

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Pheochromocytoma presenting with tremor, hypertension, tachycardia, and diaphoresis
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal; elevated triggers CT/MRI adrenals and endocrinology referral

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Hypomagnesemia contributes to tremor and neuromuscular excitability; common in alcoholism
Inflammatory markers if autoimmune or paraneoplastic etiology suspected
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal; elevated triggers further workup for inflammatory/autoimmune cause

Rare/Specialized.item: Heavy metal levels (mercury, lead, manganese, arsenic) (CPT 83825/83655/83785/82175)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: Occupational or environmental exposure causing tremor; manganese causes parkinsonism
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal; elevated triggers toxicology consultation and chelation therapy

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Autoimmune or paraneoplastic movement disorder presenting as tremor
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative; positive triggers malignancy search and immunotherapy

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Autoimmune movement disorder (stiff-person spectrum, cerebellar ataxia with tremor)
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative; positive at high titers confirms autoimmune etiology

Rare/Specialized.item: Genetic testing (LINGO1, FUS, ETM1/2, DYT genes) (CPT 81479)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: Family history of tremor or dystonia; research interest; young-onset tremor
Restless legs/periodic limb movements sometimes confused with tremor; iron deposition disorders
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal; low ferritin (<50 mcg/L) requires supplementation; very high ferritin triggers iron overload evaluation

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Cushing syndrome with tremor and proximal myopathy
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal; elevated triggers dexamethasone suppression test

Essential/First-line.timing: At presentation; document tremor type, distribution, activation conditions, frequency, associated signs (bradykinesia, rigidity, dystonia, ataxia)
Essential/First-line.target: Characterize tremor (rest, postural, kinetic, intention, task-specific); identify associated neurologic signs; laterality and symmetry

Essential/First-line.timing: At presentation and follow-up visits; compare over time
Essential/First-line.target: Large, tremulous writing (essential tremor) vs micrographia (Parkinson's); progressive change
Objective tremor severity rating; track progression or treatment response
Dysmetria and intention tremor indicate cerebellar cause; past-pointing increases with action in intention tremor

Essential/First-line.timing: STAT if acute onset tremor with other neurologic signs (weakness, ataxia, altered consciousness) suggesting structural lesion
Essential/First-line.target: Rule out hemorrhage, mass, hydrocephalus; does NOT adequately visualize posterior fossa or midbrain

Extended.timing: If structural cause suspected; atypical features; young onset; acute onset
Extended.target: Rule out midbrain/thalamic lesion (Holmes tremor), cerebellar lesion, basal ganglia pathology, Wilson disease (T2 basal ganglia changes), demyelination

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Extended.timing: If mass lesion, demyelination, or infection suspected
Extended.target: Midbrain lesion (Holmes tremor); cerebellar tumor/abscess; MS plaques; basal ganglia enhancement
Extended.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; contrast allergy; GFR <30 for gadolinium

Extended.timing: Key study to differentiate essential tremor from Parkinson's disease when clinical features overlap; order when diagnostic uncertainty persists after clinical evaluation
Extended.target: Normal striatal uptake indicates essential tremor, enhanced physiologic tremor, drug-induced tremor, psychogenic tremor; reduced striatal uptake indicates Parkinson's disease, MSA, PSP, DLB
Extended.contraindications: Pregnancy; iodine/shellfish allergy; hold interfering medications (bupropion, amphetamines, modafinil, cocaine) 2 weeks before

Extended.timing: If Wilson disease or iron deposition suspected
Extended.target: Basal ganglia T2 hypointensity (iron deposition); "face of the giant panda" sign in Wilson disease (midbrain)

Extended.timing: Objective quantification of tremor frequency and amplitude; distinguish tremor types by frequency characteristics
Extended.target: ET: 4-12 Hz; physiologic: 8-12 Hz; PD rest: 4-6 Hz; cerebellar: 3-5 Hz; Holmes: <4.5 Hz; orthostatic: 13-18 Hz

Extended.timing: If neuropathic tremor suspected; orthostatic tremor evaluation; distinguish tremor types
Extended.target: Rhythmic bursting pattern; high-frequency EMG bursts in orthostatic tremor (13-18 Hz); neuropathic tremor pattern

Extended.timing: If peripheral neuropathy suspected as contributing factor to sensory-mediated tremor
Extended.target: Sensory or sensorimotor neuropathy; demyelinating features (CIDP)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Atypical parkinsonism suspected; distinguish PD from MSA, PSP, CBD
Rare/Specialized.target: Characteristic metabolic patterns differ by diagnosis; hypometabolism in posterior cortex (DLB), frontal (PSP), asymmetric cortical (CBD)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Differentiate PD (reduced cardiac sympathetic innervation) from MSA or drug-induced parkinsonism (normal)
Rare/Specialized.target: Reduced uptake indicates PD or DLB; normal indicates MSA, DIP, essential tremor

Rare/Specialized.timing: Supportive test; olfactory dysfunction suggests underlying PD (present early) vs normal olfaction in ET or DIP
Rare/Specialized.target: Impaired indicates PD, DLB; normal indicates ET, DIP, functional tremor

Rare/Specialized.timing: Substantia nigra hyperechogenicity assessment; supports PD diagnosis
Rare/Specialized.target: Hyperechogenicity suggests PD; normal indicates ET, DIP

Rare/Specialized.timing: REM sleep behavior disorder suggests underlying synucleinopathy (PD, DLB, MSA)
Rare/Specialized.target: RBD present strongly supports underlying neurodegenerative parkinsonism

Rare/Specialized.timing: Kayser-Fleischer ring detection for Wilson disease in patients <50 with low ceruloplasmin or liver disease
Rare/Specialized.target: K-F rings present confirms Wilson disease highly likely

Immediate Management (ED/Acute Setting).item: Discontinue or reduce suspected causative medication
Immediate Management (ED/Acute Setting).indication: Drug-induced tremor; temporal relationship between medication initiation and tremor onset

doseOptions.orderSentence: Discontinue or reduce suspected causative medication N/A PO

dosing.instructions: Identify and discontinue offending agent if safe; taper if abrupt withdrawal is dangerous (benzodiazepines, antiepileptics, antipsychotics); coordinate with prescribing physician
dosing.orderSentence: Discontinue or reduce suspected causative medication N/A PO

Immediate Management (ED/Acute Setting).contraindications: Active psychosis, seizure disorder, or condition requiring the medication without safe alternative
Immediate Management (ED/Acute Setting).monitoring: Symptom resolution timeline; withdrawal symptoms; rebound of treated condition

Immediate Management (ED/Acute Setting).indication: Hypoglycemia-induced tremor with blood glucose <70 mg/dL

dosing.instructions: Administer 50 mL of D50W IV push; recheck glucose in 15 minutes; repeat if glucose remains <70 mg/dL; transition to oral carbohydrates once able

Immediate Management (ED/Acute Setting).monitoring: Blood glucose q15 min until >100 mg/dL; identify and treat underlying cause of hypoglycemia

dosing.instructions: Normal saline or hypertonic saline per sodium deficit calculation; correct sodium no faster than 8-10 mEq/L per 24 hours to prevent osmotic demyelination

Immediate Management (ED/Acute Setting).monitoring: Serum sodium q4-6h during correction; strict I/O monitoring; tremor resolution with correction

doseOptions.orderSentence: Magnesium Sulfate 4 g IV loading dose

dosing.instructions: Administer 2 g IV over 1 hour; recheck magnesium in 4-6 hours; repeat 1-2 g IV if still low; transition to oral magnesium oxide 400-800 mg daily

Immediate Management (ED/Acute Setting).monitoring: Serum magnesium levels; deep tendon reflexes; respiratory rate

Immediate Management (ED/Acute Setting).indication: Empiric symptomatic relief for functionally impairing tremor while diagnostic workup in progress; effective for postural and action tremor

dosing.instructions: Start 20 mg BID; titrate by 20 mg q3-7d based on response and tolerability; target 60-320 mg/day in divided doses; use LA formulation once optimal dose determined

Immediate Management (ED/Acute Setting).contraindications: Asthma/severe COPD; bradycardia (HR <50); second/third-degree AV block; decompensated heart failure; severe peripheral vascular disease; concurrent verapamil
Immediate Management (ED/Acute Setting).monitoring: HR, BP at each visit; bronchospasm; fatigue, depression; masks hypoglycemia in diabetics

Immediate Management (ED/Acute Setting).indication: Severe acute tremor causing significant distress or functional impairment; short-term bridge while definitive evaluation underway

dosing.instructions: 0.5-1 mg PO/IV q8h PRN for severe tremor; limit to 48-72 hours acute use; not for chronic management due to dependence risk

Immediate Management (ED/Acute Setting).contraindications: Respiratory depression; severe hepatic impairment; myasthenia gravis; concurrent opioids (relative); elderly (fall risk)
Immediate Management (ED/Acute Setting).monitoring: Sedation, respiratory rate, fall risk; do NOT prescribe for chronic use

Empiric Pharmacologic Treatment (Awaitin.indication: First-line empiric for postural/action tremor pending diagnosis; effective for essential tremor and enhanced physiologic tremor

dosing.instructions: Start 20 mg BID; titrate by 20 mg q3-7d; target 60-320 mg/day divided BID-TID; Inderal LA 60-320 mg daily once stable dose determined

Empiric Pharmacologic Treatment (Awaitin.contraindications: Asthma/severe COPD; bradycardia (HR <50); second/third-degree AV block; decompensated heart failure; severe peripheral vascular disease
Empiric Pharmacologic Treatment (Awaitin.monitoring: HR, BP; bronchospasm; fatigue; depression; cold extremities; erectile dysfunction; do NOT stop abruptly (rebound tachycardia)

Empiric Pharmacologic Treatment (Awaitin.indication: Alternative first-line for action/postural tremor; use when propranolol is contraindicated or inadequate

dosing.instructions: Start 12.5-25 mg QHS (ultra-low dose); titrate very slowly by 12.5-25 mg/week; target 250-750 mg/day in divided doses; initiation reaction (nausea, dizziness, sedation) common -- start very low

Empiric Pharmacologic Treatment (Awaitin.contraindications: Porphyria; severe sedation to initial dose; pregnancy (teratogenic)
Empiric Pharmacologic Treatment (Awaitin.monitoring: Sedation, ataxia, nausea (especially first dose -- warn patient); CBC periodically; cognitive effects in elderly

Empiric Pharmacologic Treatment (Awaitin.indication: Second-line for tremor when beta-blockers and primidone not tolerated or contraindicated

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg QHS; titrate by 300 mg q3-5d; target 900-1800 mg/day divided TID; max 3600 mg/day; adjust for renal function

Empiric Pharmacologic Treatment (Awaitin.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust); respiratory depression with opioids or CNS depressants
Empiric Pharmacologic Treatment (Awaitin.monitoring: Sedation, dizziness, peripheral edema; renal function; suicidality (rare)

Empiric Pharmacologic Treatment (Awaitin.indication: Second-line for tremor; evidence for essential tremor

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg daily; titrate by 25-50 mg/week; target 100-400 mg/day divided BID

Empiric Pharmacologic Treatment (Awaitin.contraindications: Kidney stones; narrow-angle glaucoma; pregnancy (teratogenic); metabolic acidosis
Empiric Pharmacologic Treatment (Awaitin.monitoring: Cognitive effects (word-finding difficulty, concentration); paresthesias; weight loss; kidney stones; metabolic acidosis

Empiric Pharmacologic Treatment (Awaitin.indication: Third-line for tremor; useful when anxiety is a major contributing factor; effective for orthostatic tremor

dosing.instructions: Start 0.25 mg BID; titrate by 0.25 mg q3-5d; target 0.5-4 mg/day divided BID-TID; use lowest effective dose

Empiric Pharmacologic Treatment (Awaitin.contraindications: Respiratory insufficiency; severe hepatic impairment; myasthenia gravis; avoid abrupt discontinuation
Empiric Pharmacologic Treatment (Awaitin.monitoring: Sedation, dependence, fall risk (especially elderly); cognitive impairment; limit duration; taper do not stop abruptly

Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.indication: PD tremor confirmed or strongly suspected based on clinical features and/or DaTscan; diagnostic and therapeutic trial

dosing.instructions: Start 25/100 mg TID with meals; titrate by 25/100 mg q1-2 weeks based on response; robust response supports PD diagnosis

Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.contraindications: Narrow-angle glaucoma; concurrent non-selective MAOIs; active psychosis (relative)
Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.monitoring: Nausea, orthostatic hypotension, dyskinesia (long-term); hallucinations; response to levodopa is diagnostically supportive of PD

Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.indication: Focal tremor refractory to oral medications; head tremor; voice tremor; dystonic tremor; hand tremor affecting function

dosing.instructions: 50-100 units per affected limb for hand tremor; 40-400 units for head/cervical tremor; individualized by movement disorders specialist; effects onset 1-2 weeks, peak 4-6 weeks

Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.contraindications: Infection at injection site; myasthenia gravis; pregnancy
Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.monitoring: Weakness at injection site (dose-related); dysphagia with head/voice injections; repeat q3 months

Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.indication: Hyperthyroid tremor; first-line antithyroid agent for Graves disease causing tremor

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg daily; titrate per thyroid function; typical range 5-30 mg daily; tremor resolves with euthyroid state; endocrinology co-management

Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.contraindications: Pregnancy first trimester (use PTU instead); prior agranulocytosis from antithyroid drugs; severe hepatic disease
Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.monitoring: Thyroid function tests q4-8 weeks initially; CBC (agranulocytosis risk -- instruct patient to report fever/sore throat immediately); LFTs

Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.indication: Hyperthyroid tremor; use in first trimester pregnancy or when methimazole is contraindicated

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg TID; titrate per thyroid function; typical range 100-200 mg TID; tremor resolves with euthyroid state; endocrinology co-management

Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.contraindications: Hepatotoxicity (black box warning); prior agranulocytosis from antithyroid drugs
Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.monitoring: Thyroid function tests q4-8 weeks initially; CBC (agranulocytosis risk); LFTs q1-3 months (hepatotoxicity -- black box); instruct patient to report jaundice, dark urine, abdominal pain

Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.indication: Wilson disease confirmed; first-line copper chelation therapy

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg daily; increase by 250 mg q4-7d to target 1000-1500 mg/day divided QID; take on empty stomach 1 hour before meals; pyridoxine 25 mg daily supplementation required

Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.contraindications: Penicillin allergy (relative); renal impairment; blood dyscrasias; lupus-like syndrome history
Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.monitoring: 24-hour urine copper; CBC q2 weeks for first 3 months then monthly; urinalysis (proteinuria); hepatologist co-management; neurologic monitoring for initial worsening (up to 50% of patients)

Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.indication: Wilson disease confirmed; use when D-penicillamine is not tolerated or contraindicated

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg TID; titrate to 750-1500 mg/day divided TID; take on empty stomach 1 hour before meals; separate from iron supplements by 2 hours

Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.contraindications: Iron supplementation within 2 hours (chelates iron); pregnancy (relative -- risk-benefit)
Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.monitoring: 24-hour urine copper q3-6 months; CBC; hepatic function; hepatologist co-management; fewer side effects than D-penicillamine

Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.indication: Parkinsonian features suspected but not yet confirmed; mild symptomatic benefit; avoids levodopa commitment

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg daily; increase to 100 mg BID after 1 week; max 300 mg/day; reduce dose if CrCl <50

Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (CrCl <15); seizure history (relative); livedo reticularis
Etiology-Specific Treatment (When Cause.monitoring: Renal function; hallucinations (especially elderly); insomnia (avoid evening dosing); livedo reticularis; ankle edema

Non-Pharmacologic Treatments.indication: Enhanced physiologic tremor exacerbated by caffeine; all tremor types worsened by caffeine

doseOptions.orderSentence: Caffeine reduction or elimination N/A Dietary

dosing.instructions: Reduce caffeine intake gradually to avoid withdrawal headache; target <200 mg/day or elimination; educate on hidden caffeine sources (chocolate, energy drinks, medications)
dosing.orderSentence: Caffeine reduction or elimination N/A Dietary

Non-Pharmacologic Treatments.monitoring: Tremor severity with caffeine reduction; withdrawal symptoms (headache, fatigue for 1-2 weeks)

Non-Pharmacologic Treatments.indication: Functional impairment with eating, writing, or ADLs due to hand tremor of any etiology

doseOptions.orderSentence: Weighted utensils and adaptive equipment N/A Device

dosing.instructions: Weighted utensils, stabilizing spoons (Liftware), weighted pens, two-handled cups, button hooks, rocker knives; OT assists with selection and training
dosing.orderSentence: Weighted utensils and adaptive equipment N/A Device

Non-Pharmacologic Treatments.monitoring: OT assessment and follow-up; functional improvement

Non-Pharmacologic Treatments.indication: Reduce tremor amplitude during activities; kinetic and postural tremor

dosing.instructions: 1-2 lb wrist weights during functional activities; causes fatigue with prolonged use

Non-Pharmacologic Treatments.monitoring: Arm fatigue monitoring; not for prolonged continuous use

Non-Pharmacologic Treatments.indication: Stress, anxiety, and fatigue exacerbate all tremor types; anxiety is the primary driver in enhanced physiologic tremor

doseOptions.orderSentence: Stress management and relaxation techniques N/A Behavioral

dosing.instructions: Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, mindfulness meditation, biofeedback; formal CBT if anxiety is prominent
dosing.orderSentence: Stress management and relaxation techniques N/A Behavioral

Non-Pharmacologic Treatments.monitoring: Tremor severity correlation with stress levels; obtain formal psychiatric referral if anxiety disorder identified

Non-Pharmacologic Treatments.indication: Sleep deprivation and fatigue worsen all tremor types

dosing.instructions: Target 7-9 hours sleep; consistent sleep schedule; avoid caffeine after noon; screen for sleep disorders (RBD in PD, OSA)

Non-Pharmacologic Treatments.monitoring: Sleep quality; if RBD suspected, refer for polysomnography

Non-Pharmacologic Treatments.indication: Alcohol transiently suppresses essential tremor but is NOT a treatment; chronic alcohol causes cerebellar tremor; withdrawal causes severe tremor

dosing.instructions: Educate that alcohol is NOT a treatment for tremor despite temporary relief; chronic alcohol worsens tremor long-term through cerebellar toxicity; screen for alcohol use disorder

Non-Pharmacologic Treatments.monitoring: Alcohol use screening (AUDIT-C); if alcohol use disorder identified, refer to addiction medicine

Non-Pharmacologic Treatments.indication: Avoid or modify activities that worsen tremor or where tremor causes safety risk

dosing.instructions: Plan activities for times of day when tremor is least severe; use both hands for pouring; use straws for drinking; electronic devices over handwriting when possible

Non-Pharmacologic Treatments.monitoring: Functional impact assessment at each visit

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology referral for tremor evaluation when etiology is uncertain, tremor is progressive, or associated neurologic signs present (bradykinesia, rigidity, ataxia, dystonia)

Movement disorders specialist referral for diagnostic uncertainty after initial neurology evaluation, DaTscan interpretation, tremor refractory to first-line therapy, or interventional treatment evaluation (DBS, MRgFUS)
Occupational therapy for functional impairment with ADLs; adaptive equipment assessment; handwriting strategies; workplace modification
Physical therapy for balance and gait assessment if parkinsonian features or fall risk identified
Speech therapy if voice tremor identified affecting communication or swallowing
Endocrinology referral if hyperthyroidism confirmed as tremor etiology for definitive thyroid management
Hepatology referral if Wilson disease suspected or confirmed for chelation therapy co-management
Psychiatry referral if functional (psychogenic) tremor diagnosed for integrated treatment approach; or if anxiety disorder is primary driver
Toxicology or occupational medicine if heavy metal exposure or environmental toxin suspected
Ophthalmology (slit-lamp exam) if Wilson disease suspected and patient age <50 to evaluate for Kayser-Fleischer rings
Pharmacy consult for comprehensive medication reconciliation to identify all potential tremor-inducing agents including OTC, herbal, supplements
Neuropsychology if cognitive concerns in addition to tremor (suggests neurodegenerative process)

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for sudden worsening of tremor with new weakness, speech changes, vision changes, or difficulty walking (indicates stroke or structural brain lesion)
Return immediately for high fever with severe rigidity and altered consciousness (indicates neuroleptic malignant syndrome if on antipsychotics)
Tremor has many causes, most of which are treatable or manageable; an evaluation is needed to determine the specific cause before starting long-term treatment
Bring a complete list of ALL medications (prescription, OTC, herbal, supplements) to every appointment as many common medications cause tremor
Reduce or eliminate caffeine intake as this often significantly improves tremor regardless of the underlying cause
Get adequate sleep (7-9 hours) and manage stress as fatigue and anxiety consistently worsen all types of tremor
Do not self-medicate with alcohol; while alcohol temporarily reduces essential tremor, it is not a treatment and chronic use causes permanent cerebellar damage with worsening tremor
Keep a tremor diary noting when tremor is worst, what makes it better or worse, and any new symptoms to share with your neurologist
Inform all healthcare providers about your tremor so they avoid prescribing medications that worsen it
If a specific medication was identified as causing your tremor, do NOT restart it without neurologist approval

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Reduce caffeine to <200 mg/day or eliminate entirely; taper gradually over 1-2 weeks to avoid withdrawal headache
Limit or avoid alcohol; not a treatment for tremor despite temporary relief
Regular exercise (aerobic and strength training) improves overall neurologic health and reduces tremor severity
Maintain regular sleep schedule; sleep deprivation worsens tremor
Stress reduction techniques (meditation, yoga, tai chi, biofeedback) reduce tremor exacerbation
Avoid sympathomimetics (decongestants containing pseudoephedrine, diet pills, energy supplements) which worsen tremor
Use adaptive equipment (weighted utensils, stabilizing devices) to maintain functional independence
Fall prevention measures if gait or balance affected (non-slip footwear, grab bars, adequate lighting, remove loose rugs)

differential.features: Variable (postural, rest, or mixed depending on agent)

differential.diagnosis: Arms at rest in lap, distraction with mental task (serial 7s)
differential.tests: Rest tremor emerges or increases with distraction in PD
Immediate onset postural tremor (ET); re-emergent tremor after latency (PD)
Worsening amplitude as finger approaches target
Irregular rhythm and amplitude if cerebellar dysfunction

differential.diagnosis: Contralateral voluntary rhythmic tapping during tremor observation
differential.tests: Tremor frequency shifts to match voluntary tapping frequency indicates functional
Tremor stops or markedly reduces with distraction indicates functional

differential.diagnosis: Standing with eyes open then closed (Romberg)
differential.tests: Tremor in legs present ONLY on standing; patient reports unsteadiness rather than tremor

differential.diagnosis: Search for "null point" in affected dystonic body part
differential.tests: Tremor diminishes or stops in certain positions indicates dystonic tremor

evidence.recommendation: Consensus Statement on the Classification of Tremors
AAN Practice Parameter: Therapies for Essential Tremor
MDS Criteria for Essential Tremor Diagnosis
MDS Clinical Diagnostic Criteria for Parkinson's Disease
Propranolol reduces essential tremor amplitude by 50-60%
Primidone equally effective to propranolol for essential tremor; combination is synergistic
DaTscan differentiates essential tremor (normal uptake) from Parkinson's disease (reduced uptake) with >95% sensitivity
Drug-induced tremor is among the most common causes of tremor; medication review is essential in all patients
Functional (psychogenic) tremor identified by entrainment and distractibility testing with high specificity
Wilson disease must be excluded in all patients <50 years with new-onset tremor
Orthostatic tremor is characterized by 13-18 Hz frequency on surface EMG; clonazepam first-line treatment
Holmes tremor (rubral) results from combined dopaminergic and cerebellar pathway disruption; poor response to medications
Dystonic tremor distinguished by irregular amplitude and null point; botulinum toxin effective
evidence.source: [Defazio et al. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2013](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23142961/)

evidence.recommendation: MRI-guided focused ultrasound (MRgFUS) effective for medically refractory essential tremor
evidence.source: [Elias et al. N Engl J Med 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27557301/)

evidence.recommendation: Deep brain stimulation of VIM thalamus effective for essential tremor and PD tremor refractory to medications
evidence.source: [Schuurman et al. N Engl J Med 2000](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10675426/)

evidence.recommendation: Topiramate effective for essential tremor as second-line agent
Enhanced physiologic tremor resolves with removal of exacerbating factors (caffeine, medications, metabolic correction)
Botulinum toxin effective for ET hand tremor but limited by weakness
Task Force consensus: tremor evaluation includes classification by activation condition, body distribution, and frequency

monitoring.item: Tremor severity (clinical rating: FTM scale, Bain composite score, or spiral drawing)
monitoring.frequency: Each visit; baseline and q3-6 months
monitoring.action: Worsening triggers reassessment of diagnosis; adjust treatment; order additional workup

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (look for emerging signs: bradykinesia, rigidity, ataxia, dystonia)
monitoring.action: New bradykinesia/rigidity indicates PD evolving; new ataxia indicates cerebellar pathology; order DaTscan or MRI
Increasing functional impairment triggers treatment intensification; therapy referral; evaluate interventional options

monitoring.frequency: Each visit if on propranolol or other beta-blocker
monitoring.action: HR <50 or symptomatic bradycardia triggers dose reduction; SBP <90 triggers dose reduction or agent switch
Progressive deterioration triggers diagnosis reassessment; possible PD evolving or treatment failure

monitoring.frequency: q4-8 weeks until stable, then q6-12 months
monitoring.action: Persistent hyperthyroidism triggers endocrinology management; tremor resolves with euthyroid state

monitoring.item: Drug levels (if on tremor-inducing medications that cannot be discontinued)
monitoring.action: Supratherapeutic triggers dose reduction; correlate with tremor severity

monitoring.item: Sedation and cognitive effects (if on primidone, gabapentin, benzodiazepines)
monitoring.action: Intolerable sedation or cognitive effects triggers dose reduction or agent switch

monitoring.item: Wilson disease markers (ceruloplasmin, 24h urine copper) if on chelation therapy
monitoring.action: Worsening triggers hepatology adjustment; neurologic monitoring for chelation-related neurological deterioration
Depression or anxiety triggers SSRI selection (choose agents that do not worsen tremor); psychiatry referral; note that tremor itself causes anxiety (bidirectional relationship)
Recurrent falls triggers PT reassessment; home safety evaluation; assistive device

disposition.criteria: Tremor is chronic/slowly progressive without acute neurologic emergency; no new focal deficits; no concern for stroke or acute structural lesion; outpatient neurology follow-up arranged within 2-4 weeks; immediate metabolic causes addressed; patient educated on caffeine reduction and medication review
Most patients; new-onset tremor without red flags; chronic tremor for diagnostic classification; referral within 2-4 weeks for routine evaluation
Rapidly progressive tremor; tremor with new neurologic signs (bradykinesia, ataxia, weakness); age <50 with tremor and liver disease (Wilson disease concern); significant functional impairment

Acute onset tremor with additional neurologic signs requiring expedited workup (MRI, DaTscan, labs); severe drug-induced tremor requiring monitored medication adjustment; Wilson disease with acute neurologic deterioration; tremor causing inability to perform ADLs (feeding, ambulation) without support

Diagnostic uncertainty after initial neurology evaluation; tremor refractory to first- and second-line medications; DaTscan interpretation needed; candidacy for interventional treatment (DBS, MRgFUS, botulinum toxin); suspected functional tremor requiring confirmation
Medically refractory essential tremor with significant functional impairment; adequate cognition; no surgical contraindications; confirmed diagnosis (not for undiagnosed tremor)
